Description: Operating a motor vehicle without a valid driving license is a serious offense under the Motor Vehicles Act 1988.
Notes: First offense: Rs. 5,000. Subsequent offenses may result in higher penalties and possible imprisonment.
State Variations: Some states may impose additional penalties. Check local RTO guidelines.

Description: Driving a vehicle without a valid Registration Certificate or with an expired RC is illegal.
Notes: RC must be renewed before expiry. Driving with expired RC can result in vehicle impoundment.
State Variations: Penalties may vary by state. Some states charge Rs. 2,000 for first offense.

Description: Third-party insurance is mandatory for all motor vehicles in India. Driving without valid insurance is a punishable offense.
Notes: Third-party insurance is compulsory. Comprehensive insurance is recommended for better coverage.
State Variations: Standard across all states. Vehicle may be impounded if insurance is not valid.

Description: Pollution Under Control (PUC) certificate is mandatory. Driving without a valid PUC certificate attracts penalties.
Notes: PUC certificate must be renewed periodically. For BS-IV vehicles: every 6 months, for BS-VI: every year.
State Variations: Fine is uniform across India. Certificate can be obtained from authorized PUC centers.

Description: Exceeding the prescribed speed limits on roads. Speed limits vary by road type and vehicle category.
Notes: Speed limits: Urban areas - 50 km/h, Highways - 80-100 km/h depending on vehicle type. Heavy vehicles have lower limits.
StateVariations: Penalties may vary. Some states impose Rs. 2,000 for first offense, Rs. 4,000 for repeat offenses.

Description: Driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs is a serious criminal offense with severe penalties.
Notes: Blood alcohol limit: 0.03% (30 mg per 100 ml). First offense: Rs. 10,000 fine + 6 months imprisonment. Repeat offense: Rs. 15,000 + 2 years imprisonment.
StateVariations: Penalties are uniform across India. License may be suspended or cancelled.

Description: Drivers and front-seat passengers must wear seat belts while the vehicle is in motion.
Notes: Applicable to driver and front-seat passenger. Not wearing seat belt is a traffic violation.
StateVariations: Standard fine across all states. Some states may impose additional penalties.

Description: Riding a two-wheeler without a helmet is mandatory for both driver and pillion rider.
Notes: Helmet must be ISI certified. Both rider and pillion must wear helmets. License may be suspended for repeat offenses.
StateVariations: Fine is Rs. 1,000. Some states may suspend license for 3 months on repeat offense.

Description: Using a mobile phone while driving is prohibited and attracts penalties.
Notes: Using mobile phone includes talking, texting, or any other use. Hands-free devices are allowed but not recommended.
StateVariations: First offense: Rs. 5,000. Repeat offense: Rs. 10,000. License may be suspended.

Description: Violating traffic signals, especially jumping red lights, is a serious traffic offense.
Notes: Red light violation is dangerous and can cause accidents. Fine is Rs. 5,000 for first offense.
StateVariations: Standard across India. Some states may impose higher penalties for repeat offenses.

Description: Driving on the wrong side of the road or against traffic flow is illegal and extremely dangerous.
Notes: Wrong side driving is a major cause of accidents. License may be suspended for 3 months.
StateVariations: Penalty is uniform. Repeat offenses may result in license cancellation.

Description: FASTag is mandatory for all vehicles on national highways. Driving without FASTag or with insufficient balance attracts penalties.
Notes: FASTag is mandatory on all national highways. Vehicles without FASTag must pay double the toll amount.
StateVariations: Applies to all national highways. Some state highways may have similar requirements.

Description: Carrying passengers or goods beyond the permitted capacity of the vehicle is illegal.
Notes: Overloading damages roads and is dangerous. Fine is calculated per extra ton of weight.
StateVariations: Penalties may vary. Vehicle may be impounded until excess load is removed.

Rule: Driving Without Valid Fitness Certificate (Commercial Vehicles)
Description: Commercial vehicles must have a valid fitness certificate. Driving without it is illegal.
Notes: Fitness certificate is mandatory for commercial vehicles. Must be renewed periodically.
StateVariations: Standard penalty. Vehicle may be impounded until fitness certificate is obtained.

Description: Drivers must carry valid DL, RC, Insurance, and PUC certificate while driving.
Notes: Required documents: Driving License, Registration Certificate, Insurance, PUC. Digital copies in DigiLocker are accepted.
StateVariations: Fine is Rs. 500 per missing document. Digital documents are legally valid.

Description: Parking in no-parking zones, blocking traffic, or parking in disabled parking spaces without authorization.
Notes: Parking violations vary by location. Blocking traffic or parking in no-parking zones attracts fines.
StateVariations: Fines vary by city and location. Metro cities may have higher penalties.

Description: Vehicles must display valid registration number plates as per prescribed format and specifications.
Notes: Number plates must be clearly visible, properly fixed, and comply with High Security Registration Plate (HSRP) norms.
StateVariations: Standard penalty. Vehicle may be impounded until proper number plate is fixed.

Description: Not following lane discipline, changing lanes without indicators, or driving in wrong lanes.
Notes: Proper lane discipline is essential for road safety. Use indicators before changing lanes.
StateVariations: Standard fine. Some states may impose higher penalties on highways.

Description: Commercial vehicles must have valid permits for operation. Driving without permit is illegal.
Notes: Permits are required for commercial vehicles. Different types of permits exist for different operations.
StateVariations: Penalty is uniform. Vehicle may be impounded until valid permit is obtained.

Rule: Not Giving Way to Emergency Vehicles
Description: Failing to give way to ambulances, fire trucks, or other emergency vehicles is a traffic violation.
Notes: Emergency vehicles have right of way. Not giving way can delay critical services and endanger lives.
StateVariations: Standard penalty across India. This is a serious offense.

Description: Commercial vehicle drivers must have valid medical fitness certificate.
Notes: Medical certificate must be renewed every 2 years for commercial drivers above 40 years, and every year for drivers above 50 years.
StateVariations: Standard penalty. License may be suspended until medical certificate is obtained.

Description: Driving against one-way traffic or violating one-way road restrictions.
Notes: One-way violations are dangerous and can cause head-on collisions. Always follow traffic direction signs.
StateVariations: Standard penalty. License may be suspended for repeat offenses.

Description: Learning to drive requires a valid Learner's License. Driving without LL is illegal.
Notes: Learner's License is mandatory before learning to drive. Must be accompanied by a licensed driver.
StateVariations: Standard fine. Learner must display 'L' board on vehicle.

Description: Learner drivers must display 'L' board on the front and rear of the vehicle.
Notes: 'L' board must be clearly visible. Learner must be accompanied by a person holding a valid driving license.
StateVariations: Standard fine across all states.

Description: All vehicles must have valid PUC certificate. This is separate from general vehicle fitness.
Notes: PUC certificate ensures vehicle meets emission standards. Must be renewed as per vehicle type and age.
StateVariations: Standard penalty. Certificate can be obtained from authorized PUC centers.

Description: Not stopping at zebra crossings when pedestrians are crossing is a traffic violation.
Notes: Pedestrians have right of way at zebra crossings. Vehicles must stop and allow pedestrians to cross safely.
StateVariations: Standard fine. This is important for pedestrian safety.

Description: Vehicles must have proper side mirrors (rearview and side view) as per specifications.
Notes: Proper mirrors are essential for safe driving. Both left and right side mirrors are mandatory.
StateVariations: Standard penalty. Vehicle may not pass fitness test without proper mirrors.

Description: Using horn in designated no-horn zones like hospitals, schools, and residential areas.
Notes: No-horn zones are marked for noise pollution control. Violations disturb patients, students, and residents.
StateVariations: Fines may vary by city. Metro cities have stricter enforcement.

Description: Vehicles must have valid road tax payment. Driving without paying road tax is illegal.
Notes: Road tax must be paid to the state where vehicle is registered. Tax varies by state and vehicle type.
StateVariations: Penalties vary by state. Some states may impound vehicle until tax is paid.

Rule: Violating Speed Limit in School Zones
Description: Exceeding speed limits in school zones or near educational institutions.
Notes: School zones have reduced speed limits (usually 25-30 km/h) for child safety. Violations are strictly penalized.
StateVariations: Standard penalty. Some states may have higher fines for school zone violations.

Description: Vehicles must pass emission tests and have valid PUC certificate.
Notes: Emission tests ensure vehicles meet Bharat Stage (BS) emission norms. Required for all vehicles.
StateVariations: Standard penalty. Test must be done at authorized PUC centers.

Description: Not following directions given by traffic police officers or violating their instructions.
Notes: Traffic police directions must be followed. Disobeying can lead to penalties and legal action.
StateVariations: Standard fine. May result in additional charges for obstructing traffic management.

Description: Public transport buses must have a licensed conductor. Operating without valid conductor license is illegal.
Notes: Conductor license is mandatory for bus conductors. Must be renewed periodically.
StateVariations: Standard penalty. Vehicle permit may be cancelled for violations.

Description: Vehicles exceeding height restrictions on bridges or underpasses.
Notes: Height restrictions are marked on bridges and underpasses. Violations can cause accidents and infrastructure damage.
StateVariations: Standard penalty. Vehicle may be impounded until height is reduced.

Description: Tourist vehicles must have valid tourist permits for operation.
Notes: Tourist permits are required for vehicles used for tourism purposes. Must be obtained from RTO.
StateVariations: Standard penalty. Vehicle may be impounded until valid permit is obtained.

Description: Vehicles must carry basic emergency kit including first aid, fire extinguisher (for commercial vehicles), and warning triangle.
Notes: Emergency kit is essential for road safety. Commercial vehicles must have fire extinguisher.
StateVariations: Standard fine. Requirements may vary by vehicle type.

Description: Entering areas marked with 'No Entry' signs or violating restricted entry zones.
Notes: No entry zones are marked for safety and traffic management. Violations can cause accidents.
StateVariations: Standard penalty. Some areas may have higher fines.

Rule: Driving Without Valid International Driving Permit (Abroad)
Description: Indian drivers need International Driving Permit (IDP) to drive in foreign countries that require it.
Notes: IDP is required in many countries. Must be obtained from RTO before international travel. Valid for 1 year.
StateVariations: IDP is issued by Indian RTOs. Requirements vary by destination country.

Description: Overtaking from wrong side, overtaking at curves, or violating safe overtaking procedures.
Notes: Overtaking must be done from right side. Never overtake at curves, bridges, or in no-overtaking zones.
StateVariations: Standard penalty. Dangerous overtaking can result in license suspension.

Rule: Driving Without Valid Contract Carriage Permit
Description: Contract carriage vehicles (like taxis, cabs) must have valid permits.
Notes: Contract carriage permits are required for commercial passenger vehicles. Must be renewed periodically.
StateVariations: Standard penalty. Vehicle may be impounded until valid permit is obtained.

Description: Violating right turn rules at intersections, not using proper turning signals, or cutting corners.
Notes: Right turns must be made from rightmost lane. Use indicators and follow traffic signals.
StateVariations: Standard fine. Violations can cause accidents at intersections.

Rule: Driving Without Valid Stage Carriage Permit
Description: Stage carriage vehicles (buses) must have valid stage carriage permits.
Notes: Stage carriage permits are required for public transport buses. Must be obtained from RTO.
StateVariations: Standard penalty. Operating without permit is illegal.

Description: Making U-turns where prohibited or violating U-turn rules at intersections.
Notes: U-turns are prohibited at many locations. Always check for 'No U-Turn' signs before turning.
StateVariations: Standard fine. Some locations may have higher penalties.

Rule: Driving Without Valid Goods Carriage Permit
Description: Goods vehicles must have valid goods carriage permits for commercial transport.
Notes: Goods carriage permits are required for commercial transport vehicles. Must be renewed as per regulations.
StateVariations: Standard penalty. Vehicle may be impounded until valid permit is obtained.
